unnormalised: Okay, so, you're planning a trip to India, or maybe you just need to send some cash back home? Figuring out the whole banking and cash thing can be a bit of a head-scratcher, right? Don't worry, I've been there, done that, and got the t-shirt (which, BTW, cost me ₹350 at Linking Road). Let's break down how to handle your money like a pro.
normalised: Okay, so, you are planning a trip to India, or maybe you just need to send some cash back home? Figuring out the whole banking and cash thing can be a bit of a head-scratcher, right? Do not worry, I have been there, done that, and got the t-shirt (which, by the way, cost me rupee three hundred and fifty at Linking Road). Let us break down how to handle your money like a pro.

unnormalised: First off, let's talk ATMs. You'll find 'em pretty much everywhere in bigger cities. But just a heads up, most ATMs in India have a withdrawal limit. Usually, it's around ₹10,000 to ₹20,000 per transaction. So, if you're planning on withdrawing a larger sum, you might have to do a couple of transactions or head inside a bank. Also, keep an eye out for those sneaky ATM fees your bank back home might charge. Could be like $5 per withdrawal, so factor that in!
normalised: First off, let us talk A-T-M-s. You will find them pretty much everywhere in bigger cities. But just a heads up, most A-T-M-s in India have a withdrawal limit. Usually, it is around rupee ten thousand to rupee twenty thousand per transaction. So, if you are planning on withdrawing a larger sum, you might have to do a couple of transactions or head inside a bank. Also, keep an eye out for those sneaky A-T-M fees your bank back home might charge. Could be like dollar five per withdrawal, so factor that in!

unnormalised: Speaking of banks, opening a local account might seem like a hassle, but if you're staying for a while, it's a lifesaver. Banks like SBI (State Bank of India) or HDFC are pretty common. You'll need your passport, visa, and maybe a local address proof. They usually require a min. balance, maybe around ₹2,000 to ₹5,000, depending on the bank and the type of account. The paperwork can be a bit tedious, so prepone your visit if possible.
normalised: Speaking of banks, opening a local account might seem like a hassle, but if you are staying for a while, it is a lifesaver. Banks like S-B-I (State Bank of India) or H-D-F-C are pretty common. You will need your passport, visa, and maybe a local address proof. They usually require a minimum balance, maybe around rupee two thousand to rupee five thousand, depending on the bank and the type of account. The paperwork can be a bit tedious, so prepone your visit if possible.

unnormalised: Now, for the digital peeps! UPI (Unified Payments Interface) is like, the king of transactions here. Everyone from chai wallahs to fancy restaurants uses it. Think of it as India's version of Venmo, only way more widespread. You'll need an Indian bank account and a local SIM card to set it up. Once you're in, you can pay anyone just by scanning a QR code or entering their UPI ID (it often looks something like name@bankname). Super convenient, tbh.
normalised: Now, for the digital peeps! U-P-I (Unified Payments Interface) is like, the king of transactions here. Everyone from chai wallahs to fancy restaurants uses it. Think of it as India's version of Venmo, only way more widespread. You will need an Indian bank account and a local S-I-M card to set it up. Once you are in, you can pay anyone just by scanning a Q-R code or entering their U-P-I I-D (it often looks something like name at bankname). Super convenient, to be honest.

unnormalised: Cash is still king in many smaller towns and villages. Credit cards aren't as widely accepted as in, say, the US. So, always keep some rupees handy. Think of it like this: ATMs are your knights in shining armor, UPI is your ninja assassin for quick payments, and cash is your trusty old sword when all else fails. Always a good idea to have a mix of all 3!

unnormalised: When you're exchanging currency, avoid those dodgy-looking guys on the street. Stick to authorized money changers or banks. They'll give you a much better rate, and you won't risk getting scammed with fake notes. Keep the receipt – it’s useful for converting the money back when you leave. Also, the exchange rate fluctuates, so check it online before you go. Today, it might be around ₹83 per $1, but tomorrow, who knows?

unnormalised: Don't forget to inform your bank back home about your travel plans. This way, they won't block your cards when you start using them in India, thinking it's some kind of fraudulent activity. A quick phone call or an online notification can save you a lot of headaches later. Believe me, having your card blocked while you're trying to pay for that amazing butter chicken is NOT fun.
